Introduction

Trigeminal neuralgia (TN), also known as tic douloureux, is a pain disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of sudden, severe facial pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).  TN often results from vascular compression but may be caused by demyelinating diseases or structural lesions in the pons.

Anatomy and pathophysiology



CN V provides sensation to the face, as well as innervation to the muscles of mastication (

figure 1
).  It exits the pons and divides into 3 branches:



  • Ophthalmic nerve (CN V1) passes through the cavernous sinus, exits the cranium through the superior orbital fissure (
    figure 2
    ), passes superiorly along the orbit, and then exits the orbit through the frontal bone via the supraorbital foramen.  This nerve supplies sensation to the scalp, forehead, and eyes.
  • Maxillary nerve (CN V2) passes through the cavernous sinus, leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum, and then traverses the pterygopalatine fossa to enter the maxilla via the infraorbital canal.  CN V2 exits the facial bones through the infraorbital foramen.  It provides sensation to the maxillary teeth, sinuses, and the palate.
  • Mandibular nerve (CN V3) exits the cranium through the foramen ovale (
    figure 3
    ).  It provides sensation to the lower teeth, chin, and lower lip; general sensation (not taste) in the anterior tongue; and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.


TN usually affects only the sensory components of this nerve and most commonly affects the V2 and V3 branches.



The pathophysiology of TN is most commonly related to compression of the root of CN V as it enters the pons, leading to demyelination and atrophy of the nerve (

figure 4
).  The majority of classic cases of TN are due to compression by an abnormal vascular loop, although some patients may not have a clear, identifiable vascular lesion (eg, idiopathic).  Lesions in the pons, such as tumors (eg, meningioma, schwannoma) or demyelinating plaques (from multiple sclerosis [MS]) can cause a secondary TN.

Risk factors



TN occurs most commonly in older adults (usually age >50), although it can occur in younger adults and rarely in children.  It is slightly more predominant in female than in male patients.

Clinical presentation



TN usually presents with unilateral, paroxysmal episodes of sharp, stabbing facial pain (

figure 5
).  Characteristic clinical features include the following:



  • Paroxysmal severe attacks of neuropathic pain lasting a few seconds to 2 minutes.
  • Unilateral pain involving primarily the V2 and V3 distributions.
  • Innocuous triggers and allodynia (pain to light touch).
  • Absence of other neurologic deficits on examination.


The pain of TN is often described as "stabbing" or like an "electrical shock"; it is usually unilateral and does not last more than a few seconds.  The episodes typically occur several times a day.  They are often triggered by any mild stimulus to CN V, including chewing, teeth brushing, shaving, washing the face, swallowing, or exposure to hot or cold temperatures.  Pain-free intervals often occur between episodes, although chronic dull pain may develop in later stages.  These painful episodes may occur for several months and then remit for some time before returning.



Neurologic examination in patients with classic TN (eg, due to an aberrant vascular loop) is usually normal; sensory loss over CN V is not typically seen on examination.  Patients with a secondary TN, such as from a tumor or MS, may have other focal neurologic deficits related to the underlying etiology (eg, optic neuritis due to MS).  Bilateral TN is unusual and may indicate a secondary cause.

Diagnosis



Although the diagnosis of TN is primarily clinical and based on the patient's history and characteristic pain features, all patients with suspected TN should have neuroimaging with an MRI of the brain with contrast with MR angiography to look for vascular or structural lesions that could be causing the TN.

Differential diagnosis



Conditions that mimic TN include:



  • Herpetic neuralgia:  Like TN, herpetic neuralgia has a dermatomal distribution and is associated with allodynia (ie, pain from light touch) (
    figure 6
    ).  Although pain can precede the vesicular rash by several days, a rash usually eventually appears.  In addition, the pain in herpetic neuralgia is usually not paroxysmal.
  • Cluster headache:  Cluster headaches can cause severe, paroxysmal, unilateral head and facial pain (
    figure 7
    ).  However, episodes often occur at night, last approximately 90 minutes (vs seconds), predominantly affect the upper face, and are often accompanied by autonomic symptoms (ie, miosis, lacrimation).
  • Primary stabbing headache:  These short, stabbing headaches last a few seconds.  However, unlike in TN, the pain is usually localized to a very focal spot (rather than in the V2/V3 regions), and sensory triggers are absent.
  • Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder:  TMJ disorder often causes pain with jaw movement (eg, chewing).  However, pain due to the TMJ is classically dull and waxing and waning rather than neuropathic (eg, shock-like).  Clicking/popping noises with jaw movement are common, as are ear-related symptoms (eg, ear pain, stuffiness, tinnitus).
  • Giant cell arteritis:  Giant cell arteritis causes a unilateral headache with tenderness to palpation of the temporal artery (vs allodynia in TN) (
    figure 8
    ).  However, most patients have systemic symptoms (eg, fatigue, fever) and jaw claudication (ie, pain or fatigue with chewing, relieved with rest) versus short episodes of neuropathic pain.

Management



First-line therapy for the management of classic TN is usually with carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine, antiepileptic drugs that inhibit neuronal high-frequency firing by reducing the ability of sodium channels to recover from inactivation (ie, sodium channel blockade).  They are effective in reducing episodes of pain in up to 80% of patients.  These medications may cause the following important adverse effects:



  • Hyponatremia due to increased sensitivity to antidiuretic hormone.
  • Bone marrow suppression, which may lead to anemia, agranulocytosis, and thrombocytopenia (complete blood cell counts should be monitored periodically).


Medications that can be used as second-line agents include gabapentin or lamotrigine.  Refractory cases of TN may require surgical intervention with microvascular decompression.  If TN is due to a secondary cause, such as tumor or MS, those conditions should be managed accordingly.

Prognosis



TN is a chronic condition with variable outcomes.  Many patients achieve significant pain relief with appropriate treatment, although relapses are common and long-term medication use is often needed.  Surgical interventions generally provide longer-lasting relief but carry greater risks.  The prognosis is worse in cases of TN resulting from secondary causes.

Summary



Trigeminal neuralgia (
